unnormalised: ## Embracing the Chaos: Why I Love Building Software the Indian Way
normalised: ## Embracing the Chaos: Why I Love Building Software the Indian Way

unnormalised: Okay, let's be real. Building software anywhere is a rollercoaster. But building software in India? Bhai, it's like riding that rollercoaster…blindfolded…while juggling chai cups. And yet, I wouldn't trade it for anything.
normalised: Okay, let's be real. Building software anywhere is a rollercoaster. But building software in India? Bhai, it's like riding that rollercoaster… blindfolded… while juggling chai cups. And yet, I wouldn't trade it for anything.

unnormalised: I’ve been in this game for almost 10 years, from a tiny startup in Bangalore to a massive MNC in Gurgaon. And I’ve learned one thing: we have a unique…flavour…to how we approach development. First, there's the sheer scale. I remember one project, migrating 200 TB of data, deadlines were always yesterday. Then there's the "jugaad" – that beautiful, quintessentially Indian way of finding innovative, often unorthodox, solutions. Need to scale quickly and efficiently? We'll find a way, even if it involves duct-taping together existing systems and a whole lot of caffeine.
normalised: I’ve been in this game for almost ten years, from a tiny startup in Bangalore to a massive M-N-C in Gurgaon. And I’ve learned one thing: we have a unique… flavour… to how we approach development. First, there's the sheer scale. I remember one project, migrating two hundred terabytes of data, deadlines were always yesterday. Then there's the "jugaad" – that beautiful, quintessentially Indian way of finding innovative, often unorthodox, solutions. Need to scale quickly and efficiently? We'll find a way, even if it involves duct-taping together existing systems and a whole lot of caffeine.

unnormalised: This jugaad mentality, honestly, it’s born out of necessity. Resources can be tight. Budgets? Always shrinking. So, we learn to be resourceful. We learn to make do with what we have. We learn to optimise, to squeeze every last drop of performance out of our systems. And this, in turn, fosters a culture of innovation. We aren't afraid to experiment, to try new things, even if they seem a little…unconventional. I remember one time, we used a Raspberry Pi and some open-source software to build a monitoring system for a critical server. The official solution would have cost Rs. 50,000. Our solution? Rs. 5,000.

Rupee five thousand.

unnormalised: And then there's the sheer diversity of talent. Working alongside developers from every corner of India, each bringing their own unique perspectives and expertise, is incredibly enriching. We have people who are masters of legacy systems, fluent in languages like COBOL and Fortran. And then we have the young guns, fresh out of IIT Delhi or NIT Trichy, who are pushing the boundaries of AI and machine learning. This blend of experience and innovation is what makes Indian software development so dynamic. Plus, the number of talented developers in this country is massive. I have seen a large number of developers with 7+ YoE ready to work 60+ hours a week.

I have seen a large number of developers with seven plus Y-o-E ready to work sixty plus hours a week.

unnormalised: Of course, it's not all sunshine and roses. The pressure can be immense. Deadlines are often unrealistic. And the working hours can be brutal. I've pulled my share of all-nighters, fueled by copious amounts of chai and sheer willpower. Sometimes, it feels like we’re perpetually firefighting, constantly putting out one blaze after another. But even in the midst of the chaos, there’s a sense of camaraderie, a shared sense of purpose. We're all in this together, striving to build something amazing, something that will make a real difference.

We're all in this together, striving to build something amazing, something that will make a real difference.

unnormalised: And that, ultimately, is what I love about building software the Indian way. It's challenging, it's demanding, and it's often downright crazy. But it's also incredibly rewarding. We're not just writing code; we're building solutions, we're solving problems, and we're pushing the boundaries of what's possible.

unnormalised: So, the next time you see a piece of software with "Made in India" stamped on it, remember the countless hours of hard work, the relentless dedication, and the unwavering spirit of jugaad that went into creating it. And maybe, just maybe, you'll appreciate it a little bit more. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a bug to fix. The client wants it done by 5:00 PM IST. Wish me luck! And please note that the server will be down for maintenance at 1 AM.
